qas.question: What process groups PCBs before transfer to a panel?
Is it more common for panels to have a single design or many designs?
What type of panels can also be referred to as an "array?'
Besides assembly panels, what's the other type of panel?
What step of the bare board manufacture would be impossible if panels weren't always used?

plausible_answers.text: multiple designs are mixed on a single panel.

qas.question: Usually a panel consists of multiple designs, but sometimes what?

plausible_answers.text: assembly panels - often called arrays - and bare board manufacturing panels

qas.question: The two types of portals are what?

plausible_answers.text: grouping of individual PCBs or of arrays

qas.question: Depending on what must be discussed, a manufacturing panel can consist of what?
Assemblers often mount components on portals rather than single PCBs why?

context: <a0_0>Panelization<a0_0/> is a procedure whereby a number of PCBs are grouped for manufacturing onto a larger board - the panel. Usually a panel consists of <a1_0>a single design<a1_0/> but sometimes <b5_0>multiple designs are mixed on a single panel.<b5_0/> There are two types of panels: <a2_0><b6_0>assembly panels<a2_0/> - often called arrays - and <a3_0>bare board manufacturing panels<b6_0/><a3_0/>. The assemblers often mount components on panels rather than single PCBs because <b8_0>this is efficient<b8_0/>. The bare board manufactures always uses panels, not only for efficiency, but because of the requirements <a4_0>the plating process<a4_0/>. Thus a manufacturing panel can consist of a <b7_0>grouping of individual PCBs or of arrays<b7_0/>, depending on what must be delivered.
